Events.RelatedDescription: Pushed to refs/heads/prefix-upload at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Commented on issue "build failed Nuget.resources not found." (#4637) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
So we determined this was actually an issue with our build script and not related to the client.

Currently, our build script uses https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/latest-prerelease/nuget.exe, which points to v4.0.0 instead of v4.1.0.

Fix is at https://github.com/NuGet/ServerCommon/pull/56

@oliviergauthier You can work around this by running the build script with the parameter `-BuildBranch sb-fixnugetversion`.

E.g.
```
nuget.exe -BuildBranch sb-fixnugetversion
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "ImportAzureCdnStatistics should retry blobs multiple times before deadlettering" (#4662) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently, ImportAzureCdnStatistics only processes each blob once before deadlettering. We could reduce maintenance stress significantly by modifying ImportAzureCdnStatistics to retry multiple times before deadlettering.

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Jobs/blob/a23dcbc7c10214959e89d3fda59eab34388d5beb/src/Stats.ImportAzureCdnStatistics/LogFileProcessor.cs#L74

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Fix and consolidate routing in NuGetGallery unit test configurations." (#4661) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This PR contains various fixes in NuGetGallery test infrastructure, which surface now as the gallery is checking for the `Gallery.SiteRoot` config setting. In other words: test routing and config setup must reflect a real possible scenario. 

In addition, `FormatException` were thrown due to invalid, dummy values for e-mail fields, as well as `NullReferenceException` due to service mocks that did not have all dependencies injected.

Tests are now more consistent:
* `Gallery.SiteRoot` = "http://localhost/"
* `IAppConfiguration.RequireSSL` = "true"
* all requests are HTTPS, assertions assume HTTPS (unless otherwise specified)
* we target fewer service mocks, more real implementations

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "VS 15.3 installs NetStandard dependencies for .Net framework project" (#5871) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: Package Manager Console
NuGet version:  4.3.1.4445
VS version (if appropriate): 15.3.x
OS version: windows 7
Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: unknown. At least worked with VS 15.2 and most probably the nuget version shipped with it

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create a new F# console application for .net fw 4.6.x
2. open package manager console
3. "install-package suave -whatif"

Expected: Only suave package and its dependency to fsharp.core should be resolved - as documented on suave package as dependency in case of target framework being .net fw 4.6.x
(https://www.nuget.org/packages/Suave/2.2.1).

Instead nuget resolves all NetStandard dependencies also!
(and if I remove "-whatif" really all Netstandard dependencies get downloaded and installed)

I tried it with 2 fresh f# console projects with exactly the same effect.

workaround: specify "-ignore-dependencies" and install the dependencies manually :(

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "VS 15.3 installs NetStandard dependencies for .Net framework project" (#5871) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
ok. I opened an issue at suave here: https://github.com/SuaveIO/suave/issues/650.

thx for the fast feedback and all the details - I think this issue can be closed

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Generate NuGet package on publish mode does not generate multiple target framework" (#5866) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
**VS version** = Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2017 Version 15.3.2
**OS** = Windows 10
**Project type** = .NET Standard 2.0

I have created a .NET Standard 2.0 project which target multiple .net frameworks like netstandard2.0, net461 & net47 and the package works fine in debug mode and I am able to see multiple target framework does generate on package explorer like below.  However, when I publish the package on release mode I see only .NET Standard 2.0.  Could you please tell me what I am missing?

**DEBUG** 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/554039/30236696-32d6a82e-94ed-11e7-9352-fee6d3c068d1.png)

**PUBLISH MODE**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/554039/30236741-cbbedc54-94ee-11e7-86a7-9630162370c6.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/554039/30236843-b6037570-94f1-11e7-9f16-98eecfa72d89.png)

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFrameworks>netstandard2.0;net461;net47;</TargetFrameworks>
    <GeneratePackageOnBuild>true</GeneratePackageOnBuild>
    <!--<AutoGenerateBindingRedirects>true</AutoGenerateBindingRedirects>
    <GenerateBindingRedirectsOutputType>true</GenerateBindingRedirectsOutputType>-->
  </PropertyGroup>
</Project>
```
```csharp
  public class Hello
  {
        public Hello(string name) {}
       
        #if NET461

        public Hello() {}
        
        #endif
  }
 ```

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue ".NET Core 1.1: dotnet.exe pack generates symbols nuget package, regardless of --include-symbols " (#5875) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
You can have source that has no PDB, especially if using dynamic languages, JS or embedded HTML only. Some NuGet packages are used to deploy source only (there is no requirement to have symbols with the source as the PDB is naturally built into, and from, the project that installed package of sources is housed in). One hypothetical situation is deploying packages containing, say, sources used as skeleton or scaffolding code.

I appreciate they're not always that useful :) However, if you want to _debug_ into it, when a library exists, then I agree, it needs symbols with source. 

In any event, code isn't with me atm. So I'll try it again without --include-source and see if it generates symbols.nupkg. Source is totally optional for us. Useful to know, is it the switch that takes precedence or the existence of PDB files in dotnet pack?

In any event, at the very least this highlights a docs or CLI help issue. Keep it open until I've tried it. Should be in about 6 or 7 hours time. Thanks for getting back to me.

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "Generate NuGet package on publish mode does not generate multiple target framework" (#5866) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: you could work around it by removing GeneratePackageOnBuild from your csproj, and packing your project  using dotnet.exe after you have published all target frameworks.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Solution project walking strategy for PC -> PR migration" (#5879) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Implement the solution level project walking strategy for the PC -> PR migration. 

Example, for a project graph like the following:

A -> B -> C
        B -> D -> E
F

Migrate firstly the leaf projects, because the result of their restore will impact the referencing projects too. 

So restore, C, E, F first. Then restore D, B and lastly A.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "dotnet add package fails even when an unreachable source is disabled in Nuget.config" (#5867) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @kcwms on August 22, 2017 0:18_

The "Unreachable" source is valid when connected to my corporate network. In the 1.* version of the tool I'm certain that I would simply disable the **mycorporatenuget** source and the dotnet add package command worked as expected ... or maybe I just imaged that.

## Work Around ##
manually edit %appdata%\NuGet\Nuget.Config and remove or comment out the line that includes the offending source

## Steps to reproduce
1. dotnet new console in an empty directory
1. dotnet add package log4net -s https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json

## Expected  behavior
`  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="log4net" Version="2.0.8" />
  </ItemGroup>` in *.csproj file

## Actual behavior
```
  Writing C:\Users\<me>\AppData\Local\Temp\tmp5E49.tmp
info : Adding PackageReference for package 'log4net' into project 'C:\Users\<me>\Documents\projects\nugetfail\nugetfail.csproj'.
log  : Restoring packages for C:\Users\<me>\Documents\projects\nugetfail\nugetfail.csproj...
info :   GET http://mycorporatenuget/nuget/FindPackagesById()?id='log4net'
info :   CACHE https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/log4net/index.json
info :   GET https://dotnetmyget.blob.core.windows.net/artifacts/dotnet-core/nuget/v3/flatcontainer/log4net/index.json
info :   NotFound https://dotnetmyget.blob.core.windows.net/artifacts/dotnet-core/nuget/v3/flatcontainer/log4net/index.json 463ms
log  : Retrying 'FindPackagesByIdAsyncCore' for source 'http://mycorporatenuget/nuget/FindPackagesById()?id='log4net''.
log  : An error occurred while sending the request.
log  :   The server name or address could not be resolved
info :   GET http://mycorporatenuget/nuget/FindPackagesById()?id='log4net'
log  : Retrying 'FindPackagesByIdAsyncCore' for source 'http://mycorporatenuget/nuget/FindPackagesById()?id='log4net''.
log  : An error occurred while sending the request.
log  :   The server name or address could not be resolved
info :   GET http://mycorporatenuget/nuget/FindPackagesById()?id='log4net'
error: Failed to retrieve information about 'log4net' from remote source 'http://mycorporatenuget/nuget/FindPackagesById()?id='log4net''.
error:   An error occurred while sending the request.
error:   The server name or address could not be resolved

```

## Environment data
`dotnet --info` output:
.NET Command Line Tools (2.0.0)

Product Information:
 Version:            2.0.0
 Commit SHA-1 hash:  cdcd1928c9

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.10240
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win10-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.0.0\

Microsoft .NET Core Shared Framework Host
  Version  : 2.0.0
  Build    : e8b8861ac7faf042c87a5c2f9f2d04c98b69f28d

`content of %appdata%\NuGet\Nuget.Config`
``` 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <packageSources>
    <add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" protocolVersion="3" />
    <add key="mycorporatenuget" value="http://mycorporatenuget/nuget" />
  </packageSources>
  <disabledPackageSources>
    <add key="Microsoft and .NET" value="true" />
    <add key="mycorporatenuget" value="true" />
  </disabledPackageSources>
  <packageRestore>
    <add key="enabled" value="True" />
    <add key="automatic" value="True" />
  </packageRestore>
  <bindingRedirects>
    <add key="skip" value="False" />
  </bindingRedirects>
</configuration>
```








_Copied from original issue: dotnet/cli#7491_

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "Nuget.exe restore on VS2017 seems to ignore <PackageReference>" (#5870) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "NuGet.exe update -self ignores custom package source" (#5869) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi, I have **build server in DMZ without internet access**. NuGet installed on this server using **only my own package source**; package source https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/ **is disabled**.
I need to update NuGet.exe using command "**nuget update -self**"
(current version of nuget.exe is 2.8) 
In package store is placed nupkg: **nuget.commandline.4.1.0.nupkg**
When I try run command "nuget update -self" error occurred:
 **"The remote name could be resolved: 'www.nuget.org'"**
It seems like custom package source is ignored in case of update -self command. Why? It is a bug?

OS: Win. Server 2012 R2 x64

Thanks, Petr

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet Manage Solution should prefer installed version" (#5878) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
VSFeedback Item

User ask for using used version as perfered version

When managing NuGet packages by solution, the already installed package version should be prefered.
This was done in earlier versions but was changed in the past.
If I follow the current process I run immediately into "Consolidate" issue.
At least, there should be an option to decide whether prefer newest version or used version.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Collector Task of Packages Config -> Package Reference migration related issues" (#5877) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: - [ ] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/2365 - Some assemblies in NuGet packages should be linked, not referenced (Pertains to interop assemblies and the knowledge of whether an assembly needs to be referenced. Lost when moved to the transitive world)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Test Failure]A Warning dialog pop up when creating project on VS2015" (#5506) at NuGet/Home

**NuGet Version: 4.3.0-dev-2680**

**OS Version:** Windows 10 th2_Release 

**Repro Steps:**
1. Create any C# project(Web application) on Visual Studio 2015.

A Warning dialog pop up when creating project

---------------------------
Microsoft Visual Studio
---------------------------
The 'RestoreManagerPackage' package did not load correctly.



The problem may have been caused by a configuration change or by the installation of another extension. You can get more information by examining the file 'C:\Users\mdTestAU\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\VisualStudio\14.0\ActivityLog.xml'.



Restarting Visual Studio could help resolve this issue.



Continue to show this error message?
---------------------------
Yes   No   
---------------------------


**Call stack:**
SetSite failed for package [RestoreManagerPackage]Source: 'NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager' Description: Unable to cast COM object of type 'System.__ComObject' to interface type 'Microsoft.VisualStudio.Shell.Interop.IVsSolutionBuildManager6'. This operation failed because the QueryInterface call on the COM component for the interface with IID '{61AA4EA9-018F-4394-AD31-1E76D1BF80C8}' failed due to the following error: No such interface supported (Exception from HRESULT: 0x80004002 (E_NOINTERFACE)). This operation failed because the QueryInterface call on the COM component for the interface with IID '{61AA4EA9-018F-4394-AD31-1E76D1BF80C8}' failed due to the following error: No such interface supported (Exception from HRESULT: 0x80004002 (E_NOINTERFACE)). at NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager.SolutionRestoreBuildHandler.<SubscribeAsync>d__19.MoveNext() --- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown --- at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task) at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task) at NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager.SolutionRestoreBuildHandler.<InitializeAsync>d__18.MoveNext() --- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown --- at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task) at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task) at NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager.RestoreManagerPackage.<InitializeAsync>d__2.MoveNext() --- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown --- at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task) at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task) at Microsoft.VisualStudio.Shell.AsyncPackage.<>c__DisplayClass16_0.<<Microsoft-VisualStudio-Shell-Interop-IAsyncLoadablePackageInitialize-Initialize>b__1>d.MoveNext() --- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown --- at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw() at Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.VsTask.RethrowException(AggregateException e) at Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.VsTask.InternalGetResult(Boolean ignoreUIThreadCheck) at Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.VsTask.GetResult()

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "build failed Nuget.resources not found." (#5876) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@oliviergauthier commented on [Sat Sep 09 2017](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4637)

I can't build NugetGallery. It throw the next exception :
 Impossible de charger le fichier ou l'assembly 'file:///C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Professional\MSBuild\15.0\bin\fr\NuGet.resources.dll'

it's seems related to this issue : https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/4780
I have updated Nuget with command :   .\.nuget\NuGet.exe update -self but when i launch build command again, it reset Nuget version to 4.0.0.2275

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "VS 2017: PackageType=DotnetCliTool fails to install" (#4190) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@AndreyAkinshin I understand that now, but do you know then how I can have my DbContext and migrations in my netstandard2.0 project with all my entities and domain services? I have API controllers in a netcoreapp2.0 which calls the services in the netstandard2.0 project.
This is how my current .NET Framework applications are architected and thought I would be able to replicate this with .NET Core.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue ".NET Core 1.1: dotnet.exe pack generates symbols nuget package, regardless of --include-symbols " (#5875) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @EtharAlali on September 11, 2017 14:57_

## Steps to reproduce
TeamCity dotNet build 
1. CLI dotnet pack [csproj file] --include-source /p:Version=1.0.0.61
2. Do not include symbols  (no --include-symbols) 
3. Build it 

## Expected  behavior
No symbols.nupkg created 

## Actual behavior
Definitely creates .symbols.nupkg
```
Step 8/14: Pack **[REDACT]** (.NET Core (dotnet)) (29s)
[08:44:37][Step 8/14] Starting: "C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe" pack src/**[REDACT]**.Host --output **[REDACT]**\e8c0a7eb1048b9ec\ **[Packageout]** --include-source /p:Version=1.0.0.61
[08:44:37][Step 8/14] in directory: **[REDACT]**\e8c0a7eb1048b9ec
[08:44:37][Step 8/14] Microsoft (R) Build Engine version 15.3.409.57025 for .NET Core
[08:44:37][Step 8/14] Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
[08:44:37][Step 8/14] 
[08:44:43][Step 8/14]   **[REDACT]** -> **[REDACT]**\e8c0a7eb1048b9ec\src\**[REDACT]**.Services\bin\Debug\**[REDACT]**.Services.dll
[08:44:45][Step 8/14]   **[REDACT]** -> **[REDACT]**\e8c0a7eb1048b9ec\src\**[REDACT]**\bin\Debug\**[REDACT]**.dll
[08:44:49][Step 8/14]   **[REDACT]** -> F:\BuildAgent\work\e8c0a7eb1048b9ec\src\**[REDACT]**\bin\Debug\**[REDACT]**.dll
[08:44:51][Step 8/14] C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\1.1.0\Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets(1987,5): warning MSB3277: Found conflicts between different versions of the same dependent assembly that could not be resolved.  These reference conflicts are listed in the build log when log verbosity is set to detailed. [F:\BuildAgent\work\e8c0a7eb1048b9ec\src\**[REDACT]**\**[REDACT]**.Host.csproj]
[08:45:02][Step 8/14]   **[REDACT]**.Host -> F:\BuildAgent\work\e8c0a7eb1048b9ec\src\**[REDACT]**.Host\bin\Debug\net462\win7-x86\**[REDACT]**.Host.exe
[08:45:06][Step 8/14]   Successfully created package 'F:\BuildAgent\work\e8c0a7eb1048b9ec\OctoPackages\**[REDACT]**.1.0.0.61.nupkg'.
[08:45:06][Step 8/14] C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\1.1.0\Sdks\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\build\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(141,5): warning : Issue found with package '**[REDACT]**'. [F:\BuildAgent\work\e8c0a7eb1048b9ec\src\**[REDACT]**.Host\**[REDACT]**.Host.csproj]
[08:45:06][Step 8/14] C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\1.1.0\Sdks\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\build\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(141,5): warning : Issue: Prerelease dependency in stable package. [F:\BuildAgent\work\e8c0a7eb1048b9ec\src\**[REDACT]**.Host\**[REDACT]**.Host.csproj]
[08:45:06][Step 8/14] C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\1.1.0\Sdks\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\build\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(141,5): warning : Description: A stable release of a package should not have a prerelease dependency. [F:\BuildAgent\work\e8c0a7eb1048b9ec\src\**[REDACT]**.Host\**[REDACT]**.Host.csproj]
[08:45:06][Step 8/14] C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\1.1.0\Sdks\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\build\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(141,5): warning : Solution: Either modify the version spec of dependency "**[REDACT]** [1.0.1-ci-147, )" or update the version field in the nuspec. [F:\BuildAgent\work\e8c0a7eb1048b9ec\src\**[REDACT]**.Host\**[REDACT]**.Host.csproj]
[08:45:06][Step 8/14]   Successfully created package **'F:\BuildAgent\work\e8c0a7eb1048b9ec\OctoPackages\**[REDACT]**.1.0.0.61.symbols.nupkg'.**
[08:45:06][Step 8/14] Process exited with code 0
```

Version running:



## Environment data
`dotnet --info` output:

```
.NET Command Line Tools (1.1.0)

Product Information:
 Version:            1.1.0
 Commit SHA-1 hash:  d6f4336106

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  6.3.9600
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win81-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\1.1.0
```


_Copied from original issue: dotnet/cli#7628_

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "`dotnet restore` fails with auth'd (VSTS) package source" (#5874) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @Mardoxx on September 11, 2017 17:52_

See also: https://www.visualstudio.com/en-us/docs/package/nuget/dotnet-exe

>To use `dotnet` with VSTS NuGet feeds, you'll need to specify a Personal Access Token in plain text.
> On Windows, NuGet 4 is functionally equivalent to `dotnet`, and we recommend using that instead.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "How to format Package Release notes" (#5873) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@shahabhijeet commented on [Mon Sep 11 2017](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4642)

I want to point out three issues:
1) What xml property to use in the .csproj in order for the Release notes to be visible on nuget.org package page, currently there are two properties < ReleaseNotes > and < PackageReleaseNotes >
2) Currently even if I use <![CDATA[ to format my release notes, they end up on nuget page with an in correct format
e.g.
https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/psSdkJson6/src/SdkCommon/ClientRuntime.Azure/ClientRuntime.Azure/Microsoft.Rest.ClientRuntime.Azure.csproj#L11
they end up like below
https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Rest.ClientRuntime.Azure/
version 3.3.10

3) Why don't I see my release notes in VS UI when I try to either install the nuget package or simply browsing various nuget packages.

Do we need two properties for ReleaseNotes?
Also why we cannot have a way to format our release notes, so that it's easy for customers to know what is in the package.

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "VS 15.3 installs NetStandard dependencies for .Net framework project" (#5871) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
> Anyhow it worked with VS 15.2 - maybe in that version the group without explicitly mentioned targetFramework was selected?

The way NuGet selects the group hasn't changed. I believe there was a change to the compatibility rules to allow net461 to consume additional netstandard frameworks. This might be what you are seeing, which is really confusing and unfortunate!

Opened issue "Announcing the NuGet 'Announcements' repo!" (#1) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| ------------- |:-------------| 
| _None_| https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4088|

## Announcing the **Announcements** repo!
As a step towards engaging with the community early on, we have created the **NuGet/Announcements** repo to propose new features and to get early feedback before the team starts implementing these features. This repo will be used for team announcements only. To file a bug or start a discussion, please create a new issue on [NuGet client](https://github.com/nuget/home/issues) or [NuGet server](https://github.com/nuget/NuGetGallery/issues). .

All items posted to this repo are locked, but will typically have links to separate discussion threads on one of the NuGet repos, just like this announcement can be discussed more on this issue: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4088. 
Please use these discussion threads for questions and comments about a particular announcement.

## Receiving Notifications

Subscribe to this repo to be notified about major changes, upcoming features and other noteworthy announcements in NuGet.

![subscribe](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14800916/29544263-bea081fa-869b-11e7-9c18-b576890ba049.png)

## Using the Issues list

Use the [Feature](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Feature) and [Breaking Change](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Breaking%20Change) labels to see what's new and changed.

New feature announcements will have one of the following labels:
* [Reviewing](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Reviewing) - Feature being proposed and is undergoing review within the team and the community. 
* [Reviewed](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Reviewed) - Feature has been reviewed and necessary feedback incorporated. The feature is ready to be implemented.
* [Implemented](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Implemented) - Feature has been implemented.
